name: Adaptive Cognitive Challenge Sessions
description: Older adults engage in personalized cognitive games tailored to their abilities and preferences, while caregivers remotely monitor progress and adjust difficulty to maintain motivation and support cognitive health.
scenario:
Elena Rivera eagerly wakes up and asks ALFRED to start her daily cognitive challenge session, excited to push herself with tougher games as she’s always looking to improve. She appreciates that ALFRED explains each new feature in detail, enjoying the learning process it offers. As she tackles a complex memory puzzle, her informal caregiver Sarah Thompson checks in remotely, eager to join in the fun and encourage Elena’s engagement. Sarah loves participating in these interactive games together, finding it a meaningful way to connect and motivate Elena. Meanwhile, Mike Johnson, the registered nurse overseeing Elena’s clinical progress, logs into ALFRED’s dashboard from the hospital. He quickly scans the cognitive game performance data but dismisses the gamification elements as distractions from his priority: hard clinical facts. Mike silently wishes the system would enforce standardized difficulty without room for adjustment, believing that patients like Elena need strict routines rather than playful challenges.

Later, Elena requests ALFRED to increase the difficulty level, craving a real test, but Mike’s settings override this, limiting the challenge to what he deems medically appropriate. This frustrates Elena, who feels her personal drive is stifled, yet she hesitates to confront the nurse directly. Sarah senses Elena’s disappointment during a video call and gently advocates for more personalized and enjoyable sessions, urging Mike to consider motivation as vital to cognitive health. Mike remains firm, emphasizing clinical safety and efficiency over emotional engagement, and disables Sarah’s ability to adjust the settings remotely.

Despite this tension, ALFRED continues to bridge their differing priorities. Elena enjoys the sessions that remain available, even if constrained, often chatting casually with Sarah through ALFRED’s interface, which boosts her spirits. Sarah balances her role by manually encouraging Elena to keep trying, while Mike focuses on data he can quickly interpret between hospital shifts, ignoring the social aspects. The system’s adaptability reveals the real-world challenge: Elena’s enthusiasm and Sarah’s holistic support contrast sharply with Mike’s clinical rigidity, making the pursuit of optimal cognitive care a delicate negotiation among them all.
